headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  WHEELIS, ILSE KAULBACH

docs.snippet: WHEELIS--Ilse Kaulbach, Died peacefully at home January 9, 2012 at age 96. Known professionally as Dr. Jawetz, she was a highly sought after psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who retired only last year from a robust practice of over 50 years in San F...
docs.lead_paragraph: WHEELIS--Ilse Kaulbach, Died peacefully at home January 9, 2012 at age 96. Known professionally as Dr. Jawetz, she was a highly sought after psychiatrist and psychoanalyst who retired only last year from a robust practice of over 50 years in San Francisco. She was the widow of the late Bay Area author and fellow psychoanalyst, Allen Wheelis MD. Joan Wheelis MD joan.wheelis@twobrattle.com

headline.main: Angry Birds Bypasses Windows With Latest Edition

docs.snippet: NEW YORK -- Angry Birds Space, the new edition of the world's most popular mobile phone game, will appear on Apple and Android devices but not on Microsoft's Windows Phone platform, a top executive of the game's developer said Friday.     ''We're ...

byline.original: By JON ERLICHMAN and DIANA BEN-AARON | BLOOMBERG NEWS

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK -- Angry Birds Space, the new edition of the world's most popular mobile phone game, will appear on Apple and Android devices but not on Microsoft's Windows Phone platform, a top executive of the game's developer said Friday. ''We're the No.1 app in the Windows Phone app store, but it's a big undertaking to support it, and you have to completely rewrite the application,'' said Peter Vesterbacka, chief marketing officer of Rovio Entertainment, the maker of Angry Birds.

headline.main: 'Audience Was Misled' by Daisey, The Public Theater Says

docs.snippet: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has put more distance between the theater and the monologist Mike Daisey, who was found to have fabricated details in his one-man show ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' which ju...

keywords.value: AGONY AND THE ECSTASY OF STEVE JOBS, THE (PLAY)
keywords.name: creative_works

docs.abstract: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, criticizes the monologuist Mike Daisey, who was found to have fabricated details in his one-man show The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs, which just finished a hugely successful run at the Public. Photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Oskar Eustis, the artistic director of the Public Theater, has put more distance between the theater and the monologist Mike Daisey, who was found to have fabricated details in his one-man show ''The Agony and the Ecstasy of Steve Jobs,'' which just finished a hugely successful run at the Public. In remarks offered Thursday night before a panel discussion on the fallout from the revelations, Mr. Eustis was more critical of Mr. Daisey than he had been after the radio show ''This American Life'' first disclosed that incidents recounted in the stage production, about Apple's labor practices in China, had been invented or embellished. The radio show had run a lengthy excerpt of ''The Agony and the Ecstasy,'' only to retract it after discovering the inaccuracies.

docs.snippet: GERMAIN--Lawrence. A tribute of love To a husband so dear Who is close to my heart Each day of the year. When you long for a face And a smile that is gone Memories are precious As time travels on. When my thoughts go back As they always do I bless...
docs.lead_paragraph: GERMAIN--Lawrence. A tribute of love To a husband so dear Who is close to my heart Each day of the year. When you long for a face And a smile that is gone Memories are precious As time travels on. When my thoughts go back As they always do I bless the years I shared with you. Sweet is the sleep That ends all pain I would not want you To suffer again. God took your hand We had to part It eased your pain But broke my heart. I will always love you Lawrence And will until the end For you were more Than a husband You were my very best friend Sadly missed by your loving and lonely wife, Sheila

docs.lead_paragraph: RUTHERFURD--Jody J. On March 22. Loving wife of Morton; adoring mother of Oliver, Nicholas, Victoria and Marina; doting grandmother of Henry and Sophie; devoted sister of Lynn and Bee. Memorial service will be at St. Thomas More Church on March 27 at 3:00pm. A reception to follow thereafter. In lieu of flowers, contributions may be sent to Memorial Sloan-Kettering.

docs.snippet: In this weekend's Your Money column, I look at the many insurance questions that come up about the burgeoning peer-to-peer car-sharing industry. The basic question is this: If you turn your car into a Zipcar, in effect, what are the odds that you ...
docs.abstract: Bucks blog offers reader responses to Ron Lieber Your Money column analyzing the dangers and merits of the peer-to-peer car-sharing industry. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: In this weekend's Your Money column, I look at the many insurance questions that come up about the burgeoning peer-to-peer car-sharing industry. The basic question is this: If you turn your car into a Zipcar, in effect, what are the odds that you could end up in some sort of trouble if someone rents your car and then crashes it and hurts someone? I raise three questions in the piece. First, whether you could be on the hook for an enormous judgment, beyond the $1 million in coverage that a company like RelayRides provides. Second, whether your failure to maintain the car properly could leave you exposed if someone rents it and gets in an accident because of, say, your bald tires.

headline.main: A Church In the Bronx Is Outlived By Its Spirit

docs.snippet: St. Augustine Church in the Bronx long sat atop a slight hill, like a beacon to the surrounding African-American community for whom it was home and haven. Today, the cavernous church is silent, closed down earlier this year after mounting costs an...
docs.abstract: Parishioners of St Augustine Church in the Morrisania section of the Bronx continue their relationship with area's African-American community despite the closing of the church for financial reasons; parish members are staffing the food pantry, keeping community services running, and gathering for weekly Bible study under the guidance of aging pastor, Rev Thomas Fenton. Photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: St. Augustine Church in the Bronx long sat atop a slight hill, like a beacon to the surrounding African-American community for whom it was home and haven. Today, the cavernous church is silent, closed down earlier this year after mounting costs and dwindling resources. Yet its spiritual life persists - face it, prayerful resolve is a special gift in Morrisania. Most of the parish's 300 members now trek a mile away to Our Lady of Victory. Others staff the food pantry, which feeds more than 400 people each week. And a core of devoted church ladies still gathers at a small chapel for weekly Bible study.

headline.main: Paid Notice: Deaths  CAREY, BRIAN PATRICK

docs.snippet: CAREY--Brian Patrick, on March 21, 2012. Beloved son of the late Edward V. and the late Gertrude A. Carey. Beloved brother of James E. Carey. Cherished uncle of Jacqueline H. and Patrick H. Carey. Loving brother-in-law of Margaret H. Carey. Devote...
docs.lead_paragraph: CAREY--Brian Patrick, on March 21, 2012. Beloved son of the late Edward V. and the late Gertrude A. Carey. Beloved brother of James E. Carey. Cherished uncle of Jacqueline H. and Patrick H. Carey. Loving brother-in-law of Margaret H. Carey. Devoted longtime companion of Louis Martarano. A graduate of Georgetown University, he also held an MBA and Ph.D from Columbia University. He will be grievously missed by all who knew and loved him. Friends may call Friday 2-5 and 7-9pm at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Ave. at 81st St. Mass of Christian burial Saturday, March 24 at 9:30am, Holy Trinity Church, 213 West 82nd St., NYC.
